Miller did not engage in literary criticism - he made it clear that these people are not welcome to Trump ’ s US .

Lazarus - and her friends who fought to place their words on the basis of their death - knew very well that they were carrying out a highly political act .
The sculpture should show the connections between French and American republicanism by depicting the female embodiment of freedom in an abused classic image .
Lazarus changed this meaning : in her poem , the female figure is no longer abstract - she has received a voice .
And she gives herself a very different name : mother of exiles .
The link between poem and picture is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism .
And just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , people from the right wing wanted to change it for a long time .

The great horror of Rush Limbaugh , a kind of John the Baptist for the coming of Trump , argued in 2010 that the Statue of Liberty is not inviting anyone , but rather an early neo-conservatives who bring the American flame to the world around : " Lady Liberty is moving forward .

The importance of the statue is , in fact , a question of the position of perception .
The great imaginative act of Lazarus was to see them as they were seen by the exhausted , elding but hopeful people after long and often terrible journeys on the decks of ships .
It is , in the truest sense , about seeing the world from the perspective of people seeking refuge and an opportunity to improve their lives .

When Bardina Degei cooks dinner , she does not use a cook . , , , , , , , , , , , , ,
It seldom uses a pot .

In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai regency in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweetener - locally called " nota " - directly in the fireplace .
After half an hour , the glued bones are taken out of the hands of the hand with a freeze , unwashed hands and swallowed .
Degei sits on the mud - she has no furniture - where she also carries out her daily work , for example dressing with dim water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a rootless room serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of her husband ’ s four wives , no fields were assigned to her .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , working late can be dangerous : most villagers are unemployed , and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
Nobody dares to run around in the village after 17 o 'clock ,  she says .

It is a rare insight into daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony that was admitted to Indonesia in 1969 after a controversial referendum , when only 1,026 elders were to vote by public handing over to the occupying forces .

An existing movement that stirred up independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the government of Jakarta , which maintains control of the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea covering the eastern part of the island .
The journey includes a 90-minute flight from the provincial capital Jayapura to Nabire and then a morning 5-hour drive with the rental car .
There is no public transport .
The city of about 19,000 inhabitants consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences , and of corrugated roofs converted by rust into various yellow brown tones .
Very few Indonesians have made their journey here , let alone journalists and virtually no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuans worshipped a god called Uga Tamee .
There have also been other changes .
We were not accustomed to wearing these clothes ,  says Degei and points to her lively , handwoven turban , her dark shirt and her bright skirt .
In the past we had only leaves on our bodies .
Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and some of Asia ’ s worst child mortality and literacy rates .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s gold country .

The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by the Freeport McMoran from Phoenix , is only 60 miles from Paniai , a highland province in the size of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , Freeport declined $ 3.1 billion in gold and copper .
Moreover , Papua has an estimated $ 78 billion worth of timber resources .
These riches , however , are a source of misery for the Papua , which ensure that Indonesia ’ s powerful military maintains a suffocating presence .

An investigation in the New York Times in 2005 reported that Freeport paid local military personnel and units nearly $ 20 million between 1998 and 2004 , including up to $ 150,000 to a single officer .
Papuan demands for greater autonomy threaten these golden goose and are treated mercilessly .
According to activists , more than 500,000 Papua have been killed and thousands have been raped , tortured and imprisoned by the Indonesian military since 1969 .
Mass killings in Papua ’ s tribal country in the 1970 ’ s became genocide , according to the Asia-Human Rights Commission .
In the region alone , the Indonesian police arrested more than 3,900 peaceful demonstrators last year .

We will lose everything  is stated in a 2016 Erzdiözese Brisbane report , which contains reports of the atrocities of the previous year , such as illegal executions and torture - rape and electric strikes are particularly popular after another report - and the brutal suppression of peaceful demonstrations .
It is difficult to count the number of victims as incidents happen every week ,  says Andreas Harsono , Indonesian Human Rights Watch investigator .
The screws have increased , as Papua 's resources bring an influx of settlers from other parts of Indonesia .

The population of 3.5 million inhabitants of the province is 83 % Christian , but demographic development is changing as Muslim economic migrants come from the populous islands of Java , Borneo , Sumatra and Sulawesi .
Javanese Warung-Kantinen sell fried chicken and Gado-Gado , a mixed vegetable with peanut sauce served .
Local people are fighting to stay here .

The migrants have begun to sell chickens and vegetables on the traditional market cheaper than local Papua ,  explains Abeth You , a 24-year-old Paniai native who moved to the provincial capital Jayapura .
It has cost the local Papua - the Mama [ the women ] of Papua - their market .
The Indonesian President , Joko Widodo , famously known as Jokowi , promised to address inequalities and violations of law in Papua during his 2014 election campaign .
The former carpenter secured 27 of the total 29 districts of Papua - including Paniai - on the way to the presidential palace in Jakarta .
But little has changed in Papua , and today locals feel cheated .
Our hearts have been broken because we voted for Jokowi in 2014 , with the expectation that he will fulfill our hopes that justice will be restored ,  says You .
Indeed , only two months after Jokowi ’ s inauguration in October , Paniai suffered a low point .
On December 7 , 2014 , a group of 11 children outside and sang Christmas songs in front of a campfire in Enarotali , when two Indonesian soldiers broke through darkness on a motorcycle .
The horrified children told them that they should turn their headlights on .
One of the soldiers took offence at their tone and came back with four soldiers later , according to local pastor Yavedt Tebai .
The soldiers who had drunk hunted and beat the group with their guns , said victims and witnesses .
Then one of the soldiers fired into the group of children .
One child , 16-year-old Yulianus Yeimo , was so badly beaten that he fell into the coma .
A few hours later , the building of the nearby government commission was set fire and things escalated the next day .
About 1,000 young Papua men , women , and children gathered at a football pitch in front of the local police station and the military commander ’ s center to demand justice .
They carried out ceremonial hunting arches and conducted the Waita dance - in circle and imitating a bird song - by Papuas Mee Pago-Stamm .
